00063 #if !defined(GEOGRAPHICLIB_PREC)
00064 /**
00065  * The precision of floating point numbers used in %GeographicLib.  0 means
00066  * float; 1 (default) means double; 2 means long double.  Nearly all the
00067  * testing has been carried out with doubles and that's the recommended
00068  * configuration.  Note that with Microsoft Visual Studio, long double is the
00069  * same as double.
00070  **********************************************************************/
00071 #define GEOGRAPHICLIB_PREC 1
00072 #endif
00073

00079 /**
00080  * \brief Namespace for %GeographicLib
00081  *
00082  * All of %GeographicLib is defined within the GeographicLib namespace.  In
00083  * addtion all the header files are included via %GeographicLib/filename.  This
00084  * minimizes the likelihood of conflicts with other packages.
00085  **********************************************************************/
00086 namespace GeographicLib {
00087 
00088   /**
00089    * \brief Mathematical functions needed by %GeographicLib
00090    *
00091    * Define mathematical functions in order to localize system dependencies and
00092    * to provide generic versions of the functions.  In addition define a real
00093    * type to be used by %GeographicLib.
00094    **********************************************************************/
00095   class GEOGRAPHIC_EXPORT Math {
00096   private:
00097     void dummy() {
00098       STATIC_ASSERT((GEOGRAPHICLIB_PREC) >= 0 && (GEOGRAPHICLIB_PREC) <= 2,
00099                     "Bad value of precision");
00100     }
00101     Math();                     // Disable constructor
00102   public:
00103 
00104 #if defined(HAVE_LONG_DOUBLE)
00105     /**
00106      * The extended precision type for real numbers, used for some testing.
00107      * This is long double on computers with this type; otherwise it is double.
00108      **********************************************************************/
00109     typedef long double extended;
00110 #else
00111     typedef double extended;
00112 #endif
00113 
00114 #if GEOGRAPHICLIB_PREC == 1
00115     /**
00116      * The real type for %GeographicLib. Nearly all the testing has been done
00117      * with \e real = double.  However, the algorithms should also work with
00118      * float and long double (where available).
00119      **********************************************************************/
00120     typedef double real;
00121 #elif GEOGRAPHICLIB_PREC == 0
00122     typedef float real;
00123 #elif GEOGRAPHICLIB_PREC == 2
00124     typedef extended real;
00125 #else
00126     typedef double real;
00127 #endif

00129     /**
00130      * @return \e pi
00131      **********************************************************************/
00132     template<typename T>
00133     static inline T pi() throw() { return std::atan2(T(0), -T(1)); }
00134     /**
00135      * A synonym for pi<real>().
00136      **********************************************************************/
00137     static inline real pi() throw() { return pi<real>(); }
00138 /// \cond DEPRECATED
00139     /**
00140      * <b>DEPRECATED</b> A synonym for pi<extened>().
00141      **********************************************************************/
00142     static inline extended epi() throw() { return pi<extended>(); }
00143 /// \endcond
00144 
00145     /**
00146      * @return the number of radians in a degree.
00147      **********************************************************************/
00148     template<typename T>
00149     static inline T degree() throw() { return pi<T>() / T(180); }
00150     /**
00151      * A synonym for degree<real>().
00152      **********************************************************************/
00153     static inline real degree() throw() { return degree<real>(); }
00154 /// \cond DEPRECATED
00155     /**
00156      * <b>DEPRECATED</b> A synonym for degree<extened>().
00157      **********************************************************************/
00158     static inline extended edegree() throw() { return degree<extended>(); }

00161     /**
00162      * Square a number.
00163      * @param[in] x
00164      * @return \e x<sup>2</sup>.
00165      **********************************************************************/
00166     template<typename T>
00167     static inline T sq(T x) throw() { return x * x; }
00168 
00169 #if defined(DOXYGEN)
00170     /**
00171      * The hypotenuse function avoiding underflow and overflow.
00172      *
00173      * @param[in] x
00174      * @param[in] y
00175      * @return sqrt(\e x<sup>2</sup> + \e y<sup>2</sup>).
00176      **********************************************************************/
00177     template<typename T>
00178     static inline T hypot(T x, T y) throw() {
00179       x = std::abs(x);
00180       y = std::abs(y);
00181       T a = (std::max)(x, y),
00182         b = (std::min)(x, y) / (a ? a : 1);
00183       return a * std::sqrt(1 + b * b);
00184     }
00185 #elif GEOGRAPHICLIB_CPLUSPLUS0X_MATH
00186     template<typename T>
00187     static inline T hypot(T x, T y) throw() { return std::hypot(x, y); }
00188 #elif defined(_MSC_VER)
00189     static inline double hypot(double x, double y) throw()
00190     { return _hypot(x, y); }
00191     static inline float hypot(float x, float y) throw()
00192     { return _hypotf(x, y); }
00193 #if defined(HAVE_LONG_DOUBLE)
00194     static inline long double hypot(long double x, long double y) throw()
00195     { return _hypot(x, y); }
00196 #endif
00197 #else
00198     // Use overloading to define generic versions
00199     static inline double hypot(double x, double y) throw()
00200     { return ::hypot(x, y); }
00201     static inline float hypot(float x, float y) throw()
00202     { return ::hypotf(x, y); }
00203 #if defined(HAVE_LONG_DOUBLE)
00204     static inline long double hypot(long double x, long double y) throw()
00205     { return ::hypotl(x, y); }
00206 #endif
00207 #endif
00208 
00209 #if defined(DOXYGEN) || (defined(_MSC_VER) && !GEOGRAPHICLIB_CPLUSPLUS0X_MATH)
00210     /**
00211      * exp(\e x) - 1 accurate near \e x = 0.  This is taken from
00212      * N. J. Higham, Accuracy and Stability of Numerical Algorithms, 2nd
00213      * Edition (SIAM, 2002), Sec 1.14.1, p 19.
00214      *
00215      * @param[in] x
00216      * @return exp(\e x) - 1.
00217      **********************************************************************/
00218     template<typename T>
00219     static inline T expm1(T x) throw() {
00220       volatile T
00221         y = std::exp(x),
00222         z = y - 1;
00223       // The reasoning here is similar to that for log1p.  The expression
00224       // mathematically reduces to exp(x) - 1, and the factor z/log(y) = (y -
00225       // 1)/log(y) is a slowly varying quantity near y = 1 and is accurately
00226       // computed.
00227       return std::abs(x) > 1 ? z : z == 0 ?  x : x * z / std::log(y);
00228     }
00229 #elif GEOGRAPHICLIB_CPLUSPLUS0X_MATH
00230     template<typename T>
00231     static inline T expm1(T x) throw() { return std::expm1(x); }
00232 #else
00233     static inline double expm1(double x) throw() { return ::expm1(x); }
00234     static inline float expm1(float x) throw() { return ::expm1f(x); }
00235 #if defined(HAVE_LONG_DOUBLE)
00236     static inline long double expm1(long double x) throw()
00237     { return ::expm1l(x); }
00238 #endif
00239 #endif
00240 
00241 #if defined(DOXYGEN) || (defined(_MSC_VER) && !GEOGRAPHICLIB_CPLUSPLUS0X_MATH)
00242     /**
00243      * log(\e x + 1) accurate near \e x = 0.
00244      *
00245      * This is taken from D. Goldberg,
00246      * <a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1145/103162.103163">What every computer
00247      * scientist should know about floating-point arithmetic</a> (1991),
00248      * Theorem 4.  See also, Higham (op. cit.), Answer to Problem 1.5, p 528.
00249      *
00250      * @param[in] x
00251      * @return log(\e x + 1).
00252      **********************************************************************/
00253     template<typename T>
00254     static inline T log1p(T x) throw() {
00255       volatile T
00256         y = 1 + x,
00257         z = y - 1;
00258       // Here's the explanation for this magic: y = 1 + z, exactly, and z
00259       // approx x, thus log(y)/z (which is nearly constant near z = 0) returns
00260       // a good approximation to the true log(1 + x)/x.  The multiplication x *
00261       // (log(y)/z) introduces little additional error.
00262       return z == 0 ? x : x * std::log(y) / z;
00263     }
00264 #elif GEOGRAPHICLIB_CPLUSPLUS0X_MATH
00265     template<typename T>
00266     static inline T log1p(T x) throw() { return std::log1p(x); }
00267 #else
00268     static inline double log1p(double x) throw() { return ::log1p(x); }
00269     static inline float log1p(float x) throw() { return ::log1pf(x); }
00270 #if defined(HAVE_LONG_DOUBLE)
00271     static inline long double log1p(long double x) throw()
00272     { return ::log1pl(x); }
00273 #endif
00274 #endif
00275 
00276 #if defined(DOXYGEN) || (defined(_MSC_VER) && !GEOGRAPHICLIB_CPLUSPLUS0X_MATH)
00277     /**
00278      * The inverse hyperbolic sine function.  This is defined in terms of
00279      * Math::log1p(\e x) in order to maintain accuracy near \e x = 0.  In
00280      * addition, the odd parity of the function is enforced.
00281      *
00282      * @param[in] x
00283      * @return asinh(\e x).
00284      **********************************************************************/
00285     template<typename T>
00286     static inline T asinh(T x) throw() {
00287       T y = std::abs(x);     // Enforce odd parity
00288       y = log1p(y * (1 + y/(hypot(T(1), y) + 1)));
00289       return x < 0 ? -y : y;
00290     }
00291 #elif GEOGRAPHICLIB_CPLUSPLUS0X_MATH
00292     template<typename T>
00293     static inline T asinh(T x) throw() { return std::asinh(x); }
00294 #else
00295     static inline double asinh(double x) throw() { return ::asinh(x); }
00296     static inline float asinh(float x) throw() { return ::asinhf(x); }
00297 #if defined(HAVE_LONG_DOUBLE)
00298     static inline long double asinh(long double x) throw()
00299     { return ::asinhl(x); }
00300 #endif
00301 #endif
00302 
00303 #if defined(DOXYGEN) || (defined(_MSC_VER) && !GEOGRAPHICLIB_CPLUSPLUS0X_MATH)
00304     /**
00305      * The inverse hyperbolic tangent function.  This is defined in terms of
00306      * Math::log1p(\e x) in order to maintain accuracy near \e x = 0.  In
00307      * addition, the odd parity of the function is enforced.
00308      *
00309      * @param[in] x
00310      * @return atanh(\e x).
00311      **********************************************************************/
00312     template<typename T>
00313     static inline T atanh(T x) throw() {
00314       T y = std::abs(x);     // Enforce odd parity
00315       y = log1p(2 * y/(1 - y))/2;
00316       return x < 0 ? -y : y;
00317     }
00318 #elif GEOGRAPHICLIB_CPLUSPLUS0X_MATH
00319     template<typename T>
00320     static inline T atanh(T x) throw() { return std::atanh(x); }
00321 #else
00322     static inline double atanh(double x) throw() { return ::atanh(x); }
00323     static inline float atanh(float x) throw() { return ::atanhf(x); }
00324 #if defined(HAVE_LONG_DOUBLE)
00325     static inline long double atanh(long double x) throw()
00326     { return ::atanhl(x); }
00327 #endif
00328 #endif
00329 
00330 #if defined(DOXYGEN) || (defined(_MSC_VER) && !GEOGRAPHICLIB_CPLUSPLUS0X_MATH)
00331     /**
00332      * The cube root function.
00333      *
00334      * @param[in] x
00335      * @return the real cube root of \e x.
00336      **********************************************************************/
00337     template<typename T>
00338     static inline T cbrt(T x) throw() {
00339       T y = std::pow(std::abs(x), 1/T(3)); // Return the real cube root
00340       return x < 0 ? -y : y;
00341     }
00342 #elif GEOGRAPHICLIB_CPLUSPLUS0X_MATH
00343     template<typename T>
00344     static inline T cbrt(T x) throw() { return std::cbrt(x); }
00345 #else
00346     static inline double cbrt(double x) throw() { return ::cbrt(x); }
00347     static inline float cbrt(float x) throw() { return ::cbrtf(x); }
00348 #if defined(HAVE_LONG_DOUBLE)
00349     static inline long double cbrt(long double x) throw() { return ::cbrtl(x); }
00350 #endif
00351 #endif

00353     /**
00354      * Test for finiteness.
00355      *
00356      * @param[in] x
00357      * @return true if number is finite, false if NaN or infinite.
00358      **********************************************************************/
00359     template<typename T>
00360     static inline bool isfinite(T x) throw() {
00361 #if defined(DOXYGEN)
00362       return std::abs(x) <= (std::numeric_limits<T>::max)();
00363 #elif (defined(_MSC_VER) && !GEOGRAPHICLIB_CPLUSPLUS0X_MATH)
00364       return _finite(x) != 0;
00365 #else
00366       return std::isfinite(x);
00367 #endif
00368     }
00369 
00370     /**
00371      * The NaN (not a number)
00372      *
00373      * @return NaN if available, otherwise return the max real.
00374      **********************************************************************/
00375     template<typename T>
00376     static inline T NaN() throw() {
00377       return std::numeric_limits<T>::has_quiet_NaN ?
00378         std::numeric_limits<T>::quiet_NaN() :
00379         (std::numeric_limits<T>::max)();
00380     }
00381     /**
00382      * A synonym for NaN<real>().
00383      **********************************************************************/
00384     static inline real NaN() throw() { return NaN<real>(); }
00385 
00386     /**
00387      * Test for NaN.
00388      *
00389      * @param[in] x
00390      * @return true if argument is a NaN.
00391      **********************************************************************/
00392     template<typename T>
00393     static inline bool isnan(T x) throw() {
00394 #if defined(DOXYGEN) || (defined(_MSC_VER) && !GEOGRAPHICLIB_CPLUSPLUS0X_MATH)
00395       return x != x;
00396 #else
00397       return std::isnan(x);
00398 #endif
00399     }
00400 
00401     /**
00402      * Infinity
00403      *
00404      * @return infinity if available, otherwise return the max real.
00405      **********************************************************************/
00406     template<typename T>
00407     static inline T infinity() throw() {
00408       return std::numeric_limits<T>::has_infinity ?
00409         std::numeric_limits<T>::infinity() :
00410         (std::numeric_limits<T>::max)();
00411     }
00412     /**
00413      * A synonym for infinity<real>().
00414      **********************************************************************/
00415     static inline real infinity() throw() { return infinity<real>(); }
00416   };

00418   /**
00419    * \brief %Constants needed by %GeographicLib
00420    *
00421    * Define constants specifying the WGS84 ellipsoid, the UTM and UPS
00422    * projections, and various unit conversions.
00423    **********************************************************************/
00424   class GEOGRAPHIC_EXPORT Constants {
00425   private:
00426     typedef Math::real real;
00427     Constants();                // Disable constructor
00428 
00429   public:
00430 /// \cond DEPRECATED
00431     /**
00432      * <b>DEPRECATED</b> A synonym for Math::pi<real>().
00433      **********************************************************************/
00434     static inline Math::real pi() throw() { return Math::pi<real>(); }
00435 /// \endcond
00436     /**
00437      * A synonym for Math::degree<real>().
00438      **********************************************************************/
00439     static inline Math::real degree() throw() { return Math::degree<real>(); }
00440     /**
00441      * @return the number of radians in an arcminute.
00442      **********************************************************************/
00443     static inline Math::real arcminute() throw()
00444     { return Math::degree<real>() / 60; }
00445     /**
00446      * @return the number of radians in an arcsecond.
00447      **********************************************************************/
00448     static inline Math::real arcsecond() throw()
00449     { return Math::degree<real>() / 3600; }
00450 
00451     /** \name Ellipsoid parameters
00452      **********************************************************************/
00453     ///@{
00454     /**
00455      * @return the equatorial radius of WGS84 ellipsoid
00456      **********************************************************************/
00457     template<typename T>
00458     static inline T WGS84_a() throw() { return T(6378137) * meter<T>(); }
00459     /**
00460      * A synonym for WGS84_a<real>().
00461      **********************************************************************/
00462     static inline Math::real WGS84_a() throw() { return WGS84_a<real>(); }
00463     /**
00464      * @return the flattening of WGS84 ellipsoid
00465      **********************************************************************/
00466     template<typename T>
00467     static inline T WGS84_f() throw() {
00468       // 1/298.257223563
00469       return T(1) / ( T(298) + T(257223563) / T(1000000000) );
00470     }
00471     /**
00472      * A synonym for WGS84_f<real>().
00473      **********************************************************************/
00474     static inline Math::real WGS84_f() throw() { return WGS84_f<real>(); }
00475     /**
00476      * <b>DEPRECATED</b>
00477      * @return the reciprocal flattening of WGS84 ellipsoid
00478      **********************************************************************/
00479     template<typename T>
00480     static inline T WGS84_r() throw() { return 1/WGS84_f<T>(); }
00481     /**
00482      * <b>DEPRECATED</b>
00483      * A synonym for WGS84_r<real>().
00484      **********************************************************************/
00485     static inline Math::real WGS84_r() throw() { return WGS84_r<real>(); }
00486     /**
00487      * @return the central scale factor for UTM
00488      **********************************************************************/
00489     template<typename T>
00490     static inline T UTM_k0() throw() {return T(9996) / T(10000); } // 0.9996
00491     /**
00492      * A synonym for UTM_k0<real>().
00493      **********************************************************************/
00494     static inline Math::real UTM_k0() throw() { return UTM_k0<real>(); }
00495     /**
00496      * @return the central scale factor for UPS
00497      **********************************************************************/
00498     template<typename T>
00499     static inline T UPS_k0() throw() { return T(994) / T(1000); } // 0.994
00500     /**
00501      * A synonym for UPS_k0<real>().
00502      **********************************************************************/
00503     static inline Math::real UPS_k0() throw() { return UPS_k0<real>(); }
00504     ///@}
00505 
00506     /** \name SI units
00507      **********************************************************************/
00508     ///@{
00509     /**
00510      * @return the number of meters in a meter.
00511      *
00512      * This is unity, but this lets the internal system of units be changed if
00513      * necessary.
00514      **********************************************************************/
00515     template<typename T>
00516     static inline T meter() throw() { return T(1); }
00517     /**
00518      * A synonym for meter<real>().
00519      **********************************************************************/
00520     static inline Math::real meter() throw() { return meter<real>(); }
00521     /**
00522      * @return the number of meters in a kilometer.
00523      **********************************************************************/
00524     static inline Math::real kilometer() throw()
00525     { return 1000 * meter<real>(); }
00526     /**
00527      * @return the number of meters in a nautical mile (approximately 1 arc
00528      *   minute)
00529      **********************************************************************/
00530     static inline Math::real nauticalmile() throw()
00531     { return 1852 * meter<real>(); }
00532     ///@}
00533 
00534     /** \name Anachronistic British units
00535      **********************************************************************/
00536     ///@{
00537     /**
00538      * @return the number of meters in an international foot.
00539      **********************************************************************/
00540     static inline Math::real foot() throw()
00541     { return real(0.0254L) * 12 * meter<real>(); }
00542     /**
00543      * @return the number of meters in a yard.
00544      **********************************************************************/
00545     static inline Math::real yard() throw() { return 3 * foot(); }
00546     /**
00547      * @return the number of meters in a fathom.
00548      **********************************************************************/
00549     static inline Math::real fathom() throw() { return 2 * yard(); }
00550     /**
00551      * @return the number of meters in a chain.
00552      **********************************************************************/
00553     static inline Math::real chain() throw() { return 22 * yard(); }
00554     /**
00555      * @return the number of meters in a furlong.
00556      **********************************************************************/
00557     static inline Math::real furlong() throw() { return 10 * chain(); }
00558     /**
00559      * @return the number of meters in a statute mile.
00560      **********************************************************************/
00561     static inline Math::real mile() throw() { return 8 * furlong(); }
00562     ///@}
00563 
00564     /** \name Anachronistic US units
00565      **********************************************************************/
00566     ///@{
00567     /**
00568      * @return the number of meters in a US survey foot.
00569      **********************************************************************/
00570     static inline Math::real surveyfoot() throw()
00571     { return real(1200) / real(3937) * meter<real>(); }
00572     ///@}
00573   };
00574 
00575   /**
00576    * \brief An accumulator for sums.
00577    *
00578    * This allow many numbers of floating point type \e T to be added together
00579    * with twice the normal precision.  Thus if \e T is double, the effective
00580    * precision of the sum is 106 bits or about 32 decimal places.  The core
00581    * idea is the error free transformation of a sum, D. E. Knuth, TAOCP, Vol 2,
00582    * 4.2.2, Theorem B.
00583    *
00584    * Two implementations are provided.  The "fast" one is an implementation of
00585    * Algorithm 4.1, of T. Ogita, S. M. Rump, S. Oishi,
00586    * <a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1137/030601818"> Accurate sum and dot
00587    * product</a>, SIAM J. Sci. Comp., 26(6) 1955-1988 (2005).  The accumulator
00588    * is represented by a two numbers _s + _t where _s is the result of the
00589    * normal sum and _t accumulates (approximately) the exact roundoff errors in
00590    * the summation of _s.
00591    *
00592    * The slow "non-fast" implementation follows J. R. Shewchuk,
00593    * <a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/PL00009321"> Adaptive Precision
00594    * Floating-Point Arithmetic and Fast Robust Geometric Predicates</a>,
00595    * Discrete & Computational Geometry 18(3) 305-363 (1997).  In this case,
00596    * with each addition of a number to the accumulator, _s and _t are adjusted
00597    * so that _s represents the sum to an accuracy of 1 ulp.  This may result in
00598    * considerably greater accuracy than the fast implementation (depending on
00599    * the input data).
00600    *
00601    * Approximate timings (summing vector<double> per addition)
00602    * - double:                      2ns = 1
00603    * - Accumulator<double, true>:   7ns = 3.5
00604    * - Accumulator<double, true>:  21ns = 10 -- Optimize() on each addition
00605    * - Accumulator<double, false>: 23ns = 11
00606    * .
00607    * Thus the slow method is about 3 times slower than the fast method.
00608    * However all times are negligible with the typical timings for geodesic
00609    * calculations which are roughly 2us.  Thus the default mode is taken to be
00610    * slow, \e fast = false.
00611    *
00612    * In the documentation of the member functions, \e sum stands for the value
00613    * currently held in the accumulator.
00614    **********************************************************************/
00615   template<typename T = Math::real, bool fast = false>
00616   class Accumulator {
00617   private:
00618     // _s accumulates for the straight sum
00619     // _t accumulates the errors.
00620     T _s, _t;
00621     // Error free transformation of a sum.  Note that t can be the same as one
00622     // of the first two arguments.
00623     static inline T sum(T u, T v, T& t) {
00624       volatile T s = u + v;
00625       volatile T up = s - v;
00626       volatile T vpp = s - up;
00627       up -= u;
00628       vpp -= v;
00629       t = -(up + vpp);
00630       // u + v =       s      + t
00631       //       = round(u + v) + t
00632       return s;
00633     }
00634     // Same as sum, but requires abs(u) >= abs(v).  This isn't currently used.
00635     static inline T fastsum(T u, T v, T& t) {
00636       volatile T s = u + v;
00637       volatile T vp = s - u;
00638       t = v - vp;
00639       return s;
00640     }
00641     void Add(T y) throw() {
00642       if (fast) {
00643         _s = sum(_s, y, y);     // Accumulate sum to _s with error in y;
00644         _t += y;                // accumulate y in _t
00645       } else {                  // Here's Shewchuk's solution...
00646         T u;                    // hold exact sum as [s, t, u]
00647         y  = sum(y, _t,  u);    // Accumulate starting at least significant end
00648         _s = sum(y, _s, _t);
00649         // Start is _s, _t decreasing and non-adjacent.  Sum is now (s + t + u)
00650         // exactly with s, t, u non-adjacent and in decreasing order (except
00651         // for possible zeros).  The following code tries to normalize the
00652         // result.  Ideally, we want _s = round(s+t+u) and _u = round(s+t+u -
00653         // _s).  The follow does an approximate job (and maintains the
00654         // decreasing non-adjacent property).  Here are two "failures" using
00655         // 3-bit floats:
00656         //
00657         // Case 1: _s is not equal to round(s+t+u) -- off by 1 ulp
00658         // [12, -1] - 8 -> [4, 0, -1] -> [4, -1] = 3 should be [3, 0] = 3
00659         //
00660         // Case 2: _s+_t is not as close to s+t+u as it shold be
00661         // [64, 5] + 4 -> [64, 8, 1] -> [64,  8] = 72 (off by 1)
00662         //                    should be [80, -7] = 73 (exact)
00663         //
00664         // "Fixing" these problems is probably not worth the expense.  The
00665         // representation inevitably leads to small errors in the accumulated
00666         // values.  The additional errors illustrated here amount to 1 ulp of
00667         // the less significant word during each addition to the Accumulator
00668         // and an additional possible error of 1 ulp in the reported sum.
00669         //
00670         // Incidentally, the "ideal" representation described above is not
00671         // canonical, because _s = round(_s + _t) may not be true.  For
00672         // example, with 3-bit floats:
00673         //
00674         // [128, 16] + 1 -> [160, -16] -- 160 = round(145).
00675         // But [160, 0] - 16 -> [128, 16] -- 128 = round(144).
00676         //
00677         if (_s == 0)            // This implies t == 0,
00678           _s = u;               // so result is u
00679         else
00680           _t += u;              // otherwise just accumulate u to t.
00681       }
00682     }
00683     // Perhaps these should both be _s + _t?
00684     T Sum() const throw() { return fast ? _s + _t : _s; }
00685     T Sum(T y) const throw() {
00686       Accumulator a(*this);
00687       a.Add(y);
00688       return a.Sum();
00689     }
00690   public:
00691     /**
00692      * Construct from a \e T.  This is not declared explicit, so that you can
00693      * write <code>Accumulator<double> a = 5;</code>.
00694      *
00695      * @param[in] y set \e sum = \e y.
00696      **********************************************************************/
00697     Accumulator(T y = T(0)) throw() : _s(y), _t(0) {
00698       STATIC_ASSERT(!std::numeric_limits<T>::is_integer,
00699                     "Accumulator type is not floating point");
00700     };
00701     /**
00702      * Set the accumulator to a number.
00703      *
00704      * @param[in] y set \e sum = \e y.
00705      **********************************************************************/
00706     Accumulator& operator=(T y) throw() { _s = y; _t = 0; return *this; }
00707     /**
00708      * Return the value held in the accumulator.
00709      *
00710      * @return \e sum.
00711      **********************************************************************/
00712     T operator()() const throw() { return Sum(); }
00713     /**
00714      * Return the result of adding a number to \e sum (but don't change \e sum).
00715      *
00716      * @param[in] y the number to be added to the sum.
00717      * @return \e sum + \e y.
00718      **********************************************************************/
00719     T operator()(T y) const throw() { return Sum(y); }
00720     /**
00721      * Add a number to the accumulator.
00722      *
00723      * @param[in] y set \e sum += \e y.
00724      **********************************************************************/
00725     Accumulator& operator+=(T y) throw() { Add(y); return *this; }
00726     /**
00727      * Subtract a number from the accumulator.
00728      *
00729      * @param[in] y set \e sum -= \e y.
00730      **********************************************************************/
00731     Accumulator& operator-=(T y) throw() { Add(-y); return *this; }
00732     /**
00733      * Multiply accumulator by an integer.  To avoid loss of accuracy, use only
00734      * integers such that \e n * \e T is exactly representable as a \e T (i.e.,
00735      * +/- powers of two).  Use \e n = -1 to negate \e sum.
00736      *
00737      * @param[in] n set \e sum *= \e n.
00738      **********************************************************************/
00739     Accumulator& operator*=(int n) throw() { _s *= n; _t *= n; return *this; }
00740     /**
00741      * Optimize how \e sum is stored in the accumulator.  This is a no-op for
00742      * the non-fast implementation.  It is rarely necessary to do this; however
00743      * the accuracy might be improved if this function is called every time a
00744      * million numbers (for example) have been added to the accumulator.
00745      **********************************************************************/
00746     void Optimize() throw() { if (fast) _s = sum(_s, _t, _t); }
00747     /**
00748      * Test equality of an Accumulator with a number.
00749      **********************************************************************/
00750     bool operator==(T y) const throw() { return Sum() == y; }
00751     /**
00752      * Test inequality of an Accumulator with a number.
00753      **********************************************************************/
00754     bool operator!=(T y) const throw() { return Sum() != y; }
00755     /**
00756      * Less operator on an Accumulator and a number.
00757      **********************************************************************/
00758     bool operator<(T y) const throw() { return Sum() < y; }
00759     /**
00760      * Less or equal operator on an Accumulator and a number.
00761      **********************************************************************/
00762     bool operator<=(T y) const throw() { return Sum() <= y; }
00763     /**
00764      * Greater operator on an Accumulator and a number.
00765      **********************************************************************/
00766     bool operator>(T y) const throw() { return Sum() > y; }
00767     /**
00768      * Greater or equal operator on an Accumulator and a number.
00769      **********************************************************************/
00770     bool operator>=(T y) const throw() { return Sum() >= y; }
00771   };
00772 
00773   /**
00774    * \brief Exception handling for %GeographicLib
00775    *
00776    * A class to handle exceptions.  It's derived from std::runtime_error so it
00777    * can be caught by the usual catch clauses.
00778    **********************************************************************/
00779   class GeographicErr : public std::runtime_error {
00780   public:
00781 
00782     /**
00783      * Constructor
00784      *
00785      * @param[in] msg a string message, which is accessible in the catch
00786      *   clause, via what().
00787      **********************************************************************/
00788     GeographicErr(const std::string& msg) : std::runtime_error(msg) {}
00789   };
00790 
00791 } // namespace GeographicLib
00792 
00793 #endif  // GEOGRAPHICLIB_CONSTANTS_HPP
